flashcards.title: Dacryocystitis Associated with Lacrimal Sac Dacryolith
flashcards.description: A 51-year-old woman presented with chronic dacryocystitis secondary to obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct (NLD). Her symptoms included persistent tearing and difficulty with vision due to discharge. Examination showed purulent drainage along the right medial canthus, overlying erythema, and pain upon palpitation (Figure 1). The patient subsequently underwent endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy and a large dacryolith (Figure 2) was removed from the lacrimal sac. The patient had complete resolution of symptoms one week after surgery (Figure 3). Composed of devitalized epithelial cells and calcified amorphous debris, Dacryoliths often lead to lacrimal sac distension and potential obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct [1]
flashcards.contributor: Jia Ern Ong; Matthew Benage, MD; Anthony T. Chung, MD; Audrey C. Ko, MD

images.alt: External photograph of the right periocular area demonstrating erythema
External photograph of the removed dacryolith
FPost-operative photograph taken one week after surgery shows interval resolution of edema, erythema, and swelling overlying the area of the nasolacrimal sac.

flashcards.title: Contact dermatitis secondary to artificial eyelashes
flashcards.description: This patient developed contact dermatitis from the adhesive used to attach these artificial eyelashes which were placed at a local beauty salon. Artificial Lashes - Contact Dermatitis

images.alt: Artificial Lashes - Contact Dermatitis -straight on view
Artificial Lashes - Contact Dermatitis -view from above and zoomed

flashcards.title: Basal cell carcinoma
flashcards.contributor: William Charles Caccamise, Sr, MDRetired Clinical Assistant Professor of Ophthalmology, University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry

images.alt: Basal Cell Carcinoma, Near teat duct
skin lesion has the typical characteristics of a basal cell carcinoma

flashcards.title: Canalicular Benign Squamous Papilloma
flashcards.description: This patient presented with a canalicular mass that was found, on biopsy, to be a benign squamous papilloma.

flashcards.title: Congenital ptosis
flashcards.description: This patient had bilateral myogenic congenital ptosis affecting the left eye more severely than the right. Note the absent upper lid crease and the peaked eyebrows secondary to frontalis overactivation.

flashcards.title: Conjunctival papilloma
flashcards.description: Conjunctival papillomas located in the inferior fornix are often pedunculated with a multilobulated appearance. These benign neoplasms are initiated after infection by the human papillomavirus (HPV).

images.alt: Conjunctival papillomas located in the inferior fornixt

flashcards.title: Bilateral Dacryocystoceles with Acute Dacryocystitis
flashcards.description: This patient's left side is a classic example of a dacryocystocele which typically presents as a gray to bluish mass or region of swelling inferior to the medial canthal tendon. An area of swelling above this level is worrisome for conditions such as encephalocele or dermoid tumors. Patients need to be monitored closely as secondary infections can develop.

flashcards.title: Distichiasis
flashcards.description: Distichiasis is the congenital or acquired presence of a partial or complete second row of eyelashes arising from the meibomian gland orifices. This is made possible because the meibomian glands and lash follicles differentiate from a common pilosebacious unit. Acquired causes occur after trauma or chronic irritation to the eyelid margin.

flashcards.title: Distichiasis
flashcards.description: Distichiasis is the congenital or acquired presence of a partial or complete second row of eyelashes arising from the meibomian gland orifices. This is made possible because the meibomian glands and lash follicles differentiate from a common pilosebacious unit. Acquired causes occur after trauma or chronic irritation to the eyelid margin.

flashcards.title: Entropion
flashcards.description: This photo demonstrates entropion, an inward rotation of the eyelid margin with resulting misdirection of the eyelashes. This patient was diagnosed with involutional entropion, which is caused by horizontal eyelid laxity, disinsertion of the lower eyelid retractors, and an over-riding orbicularis oculi muscle. In the photo, note the inward rotation of the lower eyelid margin with misdirected eyelashes abrading the cornea centrally and causing conjunctival injection. Also, note the "mounding" of the orbicularis oculi muscle indicative of an over-riding muscle.

images.alt: entropion, an inward rotation of the eyelid margin with resulting misdirection of the eyelashes

flashcards.title: Epiblepharon
flashcards.description: Epiblepharon is a condition in which the pretarsal orbicularis and skin form a horizontal fold that pushes the eyelashes vertically, sometimes in contact with the cornea. It is most common in children of Asian descent

images.alt: pretarsal orbicularis and skin form a horizontal fold that pushes the eyelashes vertically

flashcards.title: Subconjunctival prolapse of orbital fat
flashcards.description: Intraconal orbital fat can herniate into the subconjunctival space when Tenon's capsule is violated spontaneously or after trauma or surgery. This process appears as a unilateral or bilateral, elevated, compressible, yellow-orange mass with visible lipid globules. It is most commonly located in the superotemporal quadrant of the globe in elderly, obese men. Orbital fat that prolapsed

images.alt: bilateral orbital fat prolapse in a different patient.

flashcards.title: Kissing nevus
flashcards.description: Kissing nevi form in utero before separation of the upper and lower eyelids. They have an appearance that spans the lid margins when the eyelids are closed.

images.alt: Kissing nevi spans lower lid margins
Kissing nevi spans lower lid margins, eye closed

flashcards.title: Lacrimal gland dacryops
flashcards.description: Lacrimal gland dacryops are benign ductal cysts. It was originally suggested that they form secondary to ductal occlusion and subsequent build-up of secretions, but this has not been supported experimentally. It has been hypothesized more recently that some may form secondary to chronic inflammation of the lacrimal gland causing secondary immune response by the conjunctiva-associated lymphoid system with oversecretion of IgA and resulting osmotic effect with cyst formation. In this photograph, the cystic structure can be visualized lateral to the globe when the lids are retracted. The CT scan reveals a cystic structure in the region of the lacrimal gland without bony disruption. In this photograph, the cystic structure can be visualized lateral to the globe when the lids are retracted

images.alt: Lacrimal gland dacryops visualized lateral to the globe
CT scan reveals a cystic structure of lacrimal gland

flashcards.title: Orbital dermoid cyst
flashcards.description: This photograph was taken 1 week after the lesion was excised.

images.alt: MRI of preseptal orbital dermoid cyst

flashcards.title: Orbital Foreign Body
flashcards.description: This patient was stabbed with a pencil as seen in the CT scan images. The pencil traversed through his superior lid near the medial canthal region, passing near the globe while indenting but not penetrating it. The pencil then violated the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses with the tip breaking in the sphenoid sinus. Amazingly, this was simply pulled through the entry site without incident, the canalicular system was stented, and the lid laceration was repaired

images.alt: The pencil traversed through his superior lid near the medial canthal region, passing near the globe while indenting but not penetrating it. The pencil then violated the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses with the tip breaking in the sphenoid sinus.

flashcards.title: Enlarged muscle bellies in thyroid eye disease
flashcards.description: This patient is a 60-year-old female who has severe TED and has already has undergone bilateral orbital decompression (please note that the orbital floor and lateral orbital wall show areas of bony discontinuity). Figure 1. Axial CT scan showing enlarged muscle belly in Thyroid Eye Disease. The medial rectus muscle is marked "MR"

images.alt: Axial CT scan showing enlarged muscle belly in Thyroid Eye Disease
Coronal CT scan showing the enlarged muscle bellies in cross section

flashcards.title: Cosmetic Correction of Secondary Upper Eyelid Dermatochalasis After Upper Eyelid Ptosis Surgery
flashcards.description: Posted: April 14, 2020 The insurance coverage criteria for upper eyelid ptosis repair and upper eyelid blepharoplasty are stringent, and what defines cosmetic versus insurance-covered surgery of vision impairing conditions is clearly defined. In order to qualify for insurance-covered upper eyelid surgical procedures, a patient's upper eyelid condition must be impairing their vision.
flashcards.contributor: Austin R. Fox, MD, Audrey C. Ko, MD

images.alt: pre-surgery, post eyelid lift, and post upper eyelid blepharoplasty
before surgery, after lift drooping upper eyelids, after removing extra upper eyelid skin

flashcards.title: Conjunctival papilloma arising from the caruncle
flashcards.description: A conjunctival papilloma is a benign squamous epithelial tumor. There is a strong association of conjunctival papilloma with the human papillomavirus (HPV), most notably strains 6 and 11 (low-risk) and 16 and 33 (high-risk). Treatment consists of surgical excision with free margins, followed by cryotherapy.

images.alt: Conjunctival papilloma arising from the caruncle
Enlarge version of conjunctival papilloma arising from the caruncle

flashcards.title: Cosmetic Correction of Secondary Upper Eyelid Dermatochalasis After Upper Eyelid Ptosis Surgery
flashcards.description: Posted: April 14, 2020 The insurance coverage criteria for upper eyelid ptosis repair and upper eyelid blepharoplasty are stringent, and what defines cosmetic versus insurance-covered surgery of vision impairing conditions is clearly defined. In order to qualify for insurance-covered upper eyelid surgical procedures, a patient's upper eyelid condition must be impairing their vision.

flashcards.title: Dacryocystitis
flashcards.description: This patient was taken to the O.R. for an I&D of the lacrimal abscess with excellent resolution post-operatively. The tense, yellow abscess within the lacrimal system can be seen beneath the skin in this patient

images.alt: yellow abscess within the lacrimal system

flashcards.description: A 51-year-old woman presented with chronic dacryocystitis secondary to obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct (NLD). Her symptoms included persistent tearing and difficulty with vision due to discharge. The patient subsequently underwent endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy and a large dacryolith (Figure 2) was removed from the lacrimal sac. flashcards.title: Congenital Dacryocystocele
flashcards.description: Congenital dacryocystocele of the lacrimal sac in a newborn baby. A dacryocystocele is located just inferior to the medial canthus and presents as a purplish or greyish-blue swelling.

images.alt: Congenital dacryocystocele of the lacrimal sac in a newborn baby

flashcards.title: Ectropion
flashcards.description: This patient had a poor snap-back test as well as large distractibility of the lower eyelid. In this photo, pooling of fluorescein is also seen in the fornix of the lower lid. Interestingly, this patient also had a faint white line in the lower fornix indicating that there was likely retractor disinsertion as well.
flashcards.contributor: Lucas Lenci, MD and Andrew Doan, MD, PhD

images.alt: Dilated funduscopic examination showed severe, diffuse optic atrophy OD and bow-tie (band) optic atrophy OS

flashcards.title: Hering's Law
flashcards.description: A 62-year-old woman with a history of glaucoma and bilateral superior trabeculectomies presented with bilateral brow ptosis and right upper eyelid ptosis (Figure 1). The patient underwent bilateral brow ptosis repair by internal browpexy and right upper eyelid ptosis repair by external levator advancement (ELA). After unilateral upper eyelid ptosis repair, the patient developed contralateral ptosis (Figure 2) [2]. The reflexive descent of the contralateral upper eyelid after the unilateral raising of the ptotic eyelid is common and explained by Hering's Law. Surgical repair leads to decreased innervation to the bilateral levator palpebrae muscles, which are equally innervated [1]. The patient subsequently underwent a left upper eyelid ptosis repair by ELA
flashcards.contributor: Dabin Choi, BS; Aaron M. Ricca, MD, Audrey C. Ko, MD

images.alt: bilateral brow ptosis and right upper eyelid ptosis
left upper eyelid ptosis secondary to Hering's response

flashcards.title: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) preseptal cellulitis
flashcards.description: He is at risk for being a carrier of MRSA given his employment in a nursing home. His clinical course improved rapidly with I&D of his lesion, frequent hot compresses, and parenteral vancomycin therapy. Several months later, his appearance was back to his baseline, with no long-term sequelae.

images.alt: MRSA left eye lid from below
external face image showing Neurofibroma (NF) in the lid causing a s-shaped ptosis.
CT scan shows absence of spenoid wing
Unilateral proptosis (painless), mechanical ptosis OS, and medial canthal mass
Axial CT scan without contrast shows hypodense mass in the medial orbit
Coronal CT scan with enlarged left medial rectus muscle
Axial CT scan showing enlarged muscle and optic neuropathy (globe OS is pushed forward with strain on optic nerve).
Coronal CT scan showing mild orbital inflammation
angle recession glaucoma of the left eye treated with a prostaglandin analogue

flashcards.title: Preseptal cellulitis
flashcards.description: There is a well-demarcated area of erythema. Note, as well, the associated edema in the pre-ocular tissues. Careful assesment of vision, motility, and the remainder of the ocular exam showed no evidence of orbital cellulitis (a more serious condition). Preseptal cellulitis can be treated with oral antibiotics
flashcards.contributor: Robert B. Dinn, MD and Jordan Graff, MD

images.alt: unilateral associated edema in the pre-ocular tissues
Left eye Preseptal cellulitis, lid retracted

MRI scans showing sphenoid sinus mucocele.
MRI scans showing sphenoid sinus mucocele.

flashcards.title: Symblepharon
flashcards.description: Symblepharon is the adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva to the bulbar conjunctiva. It can be caused by some eye diseases (such as trachoma) or trauma to the eye.

images.alt: Symblepharon is the adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva to the bulbar conjunctiva
Symblepharon at site of perforating ulcer of cornea
Symblepharon caused by burn due to molten metal

flashcards.title: Bilateral chemosis in thyroid eye disease
flashcards.description: This 51-year-old man presented with acute onset of binocular diplopia, injected eyes, and periocular swelling that was initially diagnosed as episcleritis but worsened despite lubrication and topical steroids. Examination was remarkable for a restrictive strabismus, right upper and lower eyelid retraction, and right greater than left inferior chemosis. Additional imaging and serology testing confirmed the diagnosis of thyroid eye disease (TED). In the early presentation of thyroid eye disease, patients may experience chemosis, conjunctival injection, and eyelid swelling secondary to orbital congestion. For more information on TED, see the EyeRounds TED tutorial. Right eye : Minimal edema of right upper and lower eyelids, 4+ bullous chemosis from 0200 to 0930 with 2+ diffuse injection, mild inferotemporal thinning (dellen) at the limbus
flashcards.contributor: Brittni A. Scruggs, MD, PhD; Audrey C. Ko, MD; Alison K. Bozung, OD, FAAO

flashcards.title: Thyroid eye disease
flashcards.description: This patient complained of double vision on down gaze. Restriction of the right eye in attempted downgaze is evident on exam.

images.alt: thyroid eye disease Infiltration of the right superior rectus muscle is clearly seen on this CT scan

flashcards.title: Xanthelasma
flashcards.description: Xanthelasmas are yellowish papules or plaques caused by the deposition of lipid on or around the eyelids. The lesions are relatively rare, with an incidence of 1.1% in women and 0.3% in men [1]. Lesions typically appear between 40 and 60 years but may appear at younger ages as a sign of a familial dyslipoproteinemia. Approximately 50% of patients with xanthelasmas have abnormal cholesterol or triglyceride levels, and these lesions have been associated with hypothyroidism, cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome
flashcards.contributor: Austin R. Fox, MD, Angela Mahoney, and Audrey C. Ko, MD

images.alt: middle-aged man presented with bilateral symmetric yellowish lesions on the medial upper and lower eyelids

flashcards.title: Canalicular Lacerations
flashcards.contributor: Kenten Kingsbury; Spenser J. Morton, MD; and Audrey C. Ko, MD

images.alt: Probe is inserted into the punctum to reveal the lacerated end of the distal canaliculus.
Proximal lacerated end of the canaliculus (asterisk) is present deep within the medial canthus.
A visible bicanalicular silicone stent (arrow) after repair and stenting of canalicular laceration.

flashcards.title: Congenital Ptosis
flashcards.description: It is estimated that 25% of ptosis patients have their ptosis bilaterally. As in all cases of a congenital abnormality, ptosis cases should be evaluated for other congenital defects and a possible relationship to syndromes that include ptosis among their grouped abnormalities. Where trachoma is endemic, a diagnosis of ptosis trachomatosa must be considered in the differential diagnosis. This patient does not have trachoma

images.alt: two eyes ahown one with congential ptosis

flashcards.title: Kearns-Sayre syndrome
flashcards.description: Posted: 07/01/2024 25 year-old female presented with bilateral ptosis since age 18, severe ophthalmoplegia, and salt-and-pepper retinopathy. She also had short stature at 5'1.8", fatigue, and weakness of her face, neck, and proximal extremities. She had undergone previous surgery for bilateral upper eyelid ptosis. She had poor levator function of both eyes. ERG showed global photoreceptor dysfunction

images.alt: Severe limitation in all ductions bilaterally.
Right eye with normal optic nerve and salt-and-pepper retinopathy.
Left eye with normal optic nerve and salt-and-pepper retinopathy.
